populationSmartphones.summary: This calculation uses US EPA data on the carbon emissions generated by charging smartphones alongside UK ONS population data from 2020, filtered by those aged 11 and over (when most first acquire a smartphone) to calculate what percentage of a city's population would have to charge their smartphones to generate the same carbon emissions as a given flight.
populationSmartphones.calculation:
[14.46 Wh – (22 hours x 0.13 Watts)] x 1 kWh/1,000 Wh = 0.012 kWh/smartphone charged 
0.012 kWh/charge x 1, 562.4 pounds CO2/MWh delivered electricity x 1 MWh/1,000 kWh x 1 metric ton/2,204.6 lbs = 8.22 x 10-6 metric tons CO2/smartphone charged

timeSmartphones.summary: This calculation uses US EPA data on the carbon emissions generated by charging smartphones against an assumption that someone will charge their phone once per day.
timeSmartphones.calculation:
[14.46 Wh – (22 hours x 0.13 Watts)] x 1 kWh = 0.012 kWh/smartphone charged 
0.012 kWh/charge x 1, 562.4 pounds CO2/MWh delivered electricity x 1 MWh x 1 metric ton/2,204.6 lbs = 8.22 x 10-6 metric tons CO2/smartphone charged

lightbulbs.summary: This calculation uses data from the Ember environmental non-profit think tank on the UK's carbon intensity from generating electricity against an assumed average wattage of 13.5W for a LED or CFL lightbulb to calculate how many years a bulb would have to be left on to generate the same carbon emissions as a given flight.
lightbulbs.calculation:
13.5W (average LED/CFL bulb) x 24 = 0.324kWh 
 0.324kWh x 236g CO₂e/kWh (UK carbon intensity) = 0.076kg CO₂e/day

commutes.summary: This calculation uses an assumed approximate calculation of 2.3kg CO₂e/litre of petrol (based on the combustion of hydrocarbons), GOV.UK average miles per litre of a new car sales in the UK of 11.5 miles per liter, against and ONS data supporting an average commute of 7 miles in the UK.
